Dialogue: Let's stop fencing with words, huh? Bernard told me to come here, just before he died.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: You know it as well as I do. Now I came to make a business proposition. And I don't see how you can turn it down.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: You want to talk here?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Okay. First of all, I haven't uttered one word of what Bernard told to before he died. And I won't. Frankly I'm not interested in political intrigue, and I don't care who it is you're going to kill here in London. All I want is that boy, and I'll get on the first plane for America.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Now that isn't all.   If money will do anything...

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: You told him to call the police.   Now don't try to bluff me like that!

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: You don't know Louis Bernard?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: And you don't have any idea what went on in Marrakesh yesterday, or where my boy is?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Now just a minute. Take it easy. I obviously got the wrong place. Now stay away from me.

Speaker: val
Dialogue: ...and back at our flat, after the first night, Chris had the nerve to suggest that the sketch where Bud Flanagan comes in dressed up as the Countess was unconvincing ... that no matter how well-got-up Bud Flanagan was, even if he were dressed by Hartnell, nobody would believe he was an aristocrat. So I said, 'Look Chris, why don't you cut William Hickey's column out of the paper?! --

Speaker: val
Dialogue: Jo. Jo.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: val
Dialogue: What's become of that unpredictable husband of yours?  He's been gone over an hour.

Speaker: val
Dialogue: Who was it he went to see?   Some man named...  ...what was it...Church?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: No.   No...you mean Chappell!

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: It's not a man, it's a place! Ambrose Chapel! Ambrose Chapel! It has to be!

Speaker: j0
Dialogue: Do they list chapels in the London Telephone Directory?

Speaker: val
Dialogue: Let's a take a look.

Speaker: val
Dialogue: Here it is, Ambrose Chapel, 17 Ambrose Street, West Two.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: I'm very sorry.

Speaker: cindy
Dialogue: There's something weird going on around here that I can't follow.

Speaker: val
Dialogue: Let's see if we can figure this out. First of all there was a man named to uh...

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Ambrose Chapel.

Speaker: cindy
Dialogue: And Ben rushed off to see him.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Then Jo said it wasn't a man, but a place and she dashed off.

Speaker: jan
Dialogue: Don't mention it again or I might dash off.

Speaker: cindy
Dialogue: What a temptation.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Can you fathom it, Val?

Speaker: val
Dialogue: It must be a now American gag.    I'll ask Danny about it.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Where's Jo?

Speaker: val
Dialogue: She's just gone off to Ambrose Chapel.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: But -- but, that's where I've been...

Speaker: val
Dialogue: It isn't your Ambrose Chapel!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: It isn't a he! It's an it!     A building.

Speaker: cindy
Dialogue: She's just gone there.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Where is it!     What's the address?

Speaker: val
Dialogue: 17 Ambrose Street, Bayswater.

Speaker: jan
Dialogue: Doctor! Doctor!      It's Jo!   Come back -- it's Jo.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Jo?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Ben -- Ben, darling...what happened -- did you find anything?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: No -- I drew a complete blank.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Then it must be the chapel - and I've found it, Ben. It's just a short way from here. It was a crazy thing to do --

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: I have the address, Jo. Now stay there until I get there...and don't do anything!

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: I'll meet you outside.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Will you stick around? We'll be back as soon as we can. I don't know how to thank you.

Speaker: hank
Dialogue: Three men! You don't know much about checkers, do you?

Speaker: hank
Dialogue: Can I finish? I'm winning?

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: And he'd better have another sleeping pill...I've got to get downstairs --

Speaker: hank
Dialogue: I guess so.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Hurry up if you want to finish this game.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: That's not a very orthodox sentiment.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Two excellent tickets for the concert at the Albert Hall -- with my compliments.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Your box is nicely placed, or shall we say strategically placed.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Now for the most important part.

Speaker: rien
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: A record of the delightful Picco they will play tonight.

Speaker: rien
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Music is less in your line than marksmanship. If you will listen, my friend, I will play for you the exact moment at which you can shoot. Now listen carefully.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Let me do it for you again.   Now listen for the cymbal crash.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: You see at such a moment your shot will not be heard. The listeners will not even be disturbed. I think the composer would have appreciated that. No one will know.

Speaker: rien
Dialogue: None except one you mean.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Ah, yes -- if you are clever, my friend. Any questions musical or otherwise?

Speaker: rien
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: There's's one comforting thought. It happens early in the evening. I hope I won't upset you if I say there's time for one shot only. If you need another, the risk is yours.

Speaker: rien
Dialogue: I do not take risks.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: That's a comfort -- traipsing all the way down to Marrakesh to fetch you I should like you to do me credit.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Your distinguished target's on the way there now. A car is waiting for you downstairs at the back entrance. You will pick up a Miss Benson on your way. She will be your companion in the box. She's there to lend an air of respectability...if that's possible.

Speaker: rien
Dialogue: You will have the money when I return?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: I think you can trust me.

Speaker: rien
Dialogue: What is your English proverb -- a wolf in Sheep's clothing?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: I think you    had better be going. It is impolite    to be late for a concert. It would be    awkward if they made you wait until    the first selection is over.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: See him downstairs, my dear.  I'm sorry you must sneak out the back way, but we have to preserve our respectable front.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: There it is.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: You may have just hit it right on the nose. You can't be farther wrong than I was with my Ambrose Chapel. Let's go.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Ben, should we get some help from the police?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: No, honey, please, no -- let's take a crack at this alone.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: This looks like mother wild goose chase.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Let's wait and look around...

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Look who's coming down the aisle.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Brothers and Sisters: The subject of my address this evening is adversity. The average life, yours and mine, is often harassed and perplexed by cruelties and disappointments beyond our control.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: That's Buchanan's phone number. Go on out and call him and ask him to surround the place with police.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: What if he asks me...

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Tell him...tell him everything. This is the time. I'm sure Hank is around here some place.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Ben, I don't want to leave you.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: I don't know how else to do it, honey.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Few of us pause to think how life's adversities work in our behalf, to make better men and women of us.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Well this is a pleasant surprise, Doctor.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Where's my boy, Drayton?

Dialogue: He's upstairs. As a matter of fact you've just come in time to help my wife with Hank's food. Seems Hank doesn't care much for English cooking.  Drayton's eyes stray to the back of the church as he talks. Ben, noticing Drayton's eye movement, follows it cautiously. Speaker: ben
Dialogue: What do you want? I'll give you money and keep my mouth shut. All I want is my boy.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: And what about your wife? Did she go outside just to get some fresh air.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Tell me what you want.   I'll do anything.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: All right -- you'll see your boy in good time.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Hank! Hank McKenna!    Hank!   Where are you? Hank! Hank!

Speaker: hank
Dialogue: Daddy!   Daddy, I'm here!   Dad -

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: ...And Ben is in there now, watching the both of them!

Speaker: j0
Dialogue: He sent me out to call you -- so we could do something before they get away.

Dialogue: I see, Mrs. McKenna -- and you believe your son is somewhere in the chapel?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: I don't know, I don't know where he is...but at least these people will know -- the Draytons. If you'd only send somebody to get them.

Dialogue: I'm afraid it isn't quite as easy as all that.

Dialogue: I'm awfully sorry, but I simply can't get hold of him just now. He's gone to a rather important diplomatic affair -- at the Albert Hall.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Well call him there, please!    Call him!

Speaker: woburn
Dialogue: He's on his way. I don't know quite --

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Then can't you do anything -- right away -- before we lose the Draytons?

Speaker: woburn
Dialogue: I assure you, I'll do all I cant as soon as I can.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: We don't have days to do this. It's a matter of minutes. Can't you send the police. Or do I have to go to the Albert Hall myself.

Dialogue: That won't be necessary. I'll see that the chapel is put under immediate observation. By the time you get back a police car should be there. Please return to your husband, tell him to come straight out of the chapel, and let the police take over.

Speaker: woburn
Dialogue: Woburn, Special Branch, hold on.  I must ring off now, Mrs. McKenna. Please believe me, I'll have everything laid on.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: There's nobody there!

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Are you Mrs. McKenna?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Yes, but something's wrong. A few minutes ago the place was full of people, and now there's nobody!

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Our orders are to keep it under observation until a Scotland Yard car arrives.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: My husband's in there. There must have been thirty or forty people... and now...

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: When was this?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: It couldn't...it couldn't have been more than five minutes ago!

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Let's take a look.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: I told Mr. Woburn he had to hurry.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: I tried that. It's looked, Let's force it open.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I'm sorry, madam, we can't break in.  Requires a search warrant. It's the law, you see.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Couldn't you get one?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: It all takes time. We'll have a look round, shall we? Matthews, you take the other end.

Speaker: matthews
Dialogue: All right.  They start around the corner to inspect the sides of the Chapel.

Speaker: matthews
Dialogue: There's no one there, sir.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Are you quite certain the place was full of people -- only a few minutes ago?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Of course I'm certain. I was there myself, sitting next to my husband. He sent me out to call Scotland Yard.

Speaker: j0
Dialogue: It's much too complicated to explain.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: We'll just have to sit tight and wait for the car to arrive from the Yard.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: So far as we can make out, sir, there's no sign of life. I see, very good, Sir.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Walden, you'll stay here, till the car arrives from the Yard.

Speaker: walden
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: That's all, Matthews.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: You're not leaving?

Speaker: patterso
Dialogue: Orders, madam. Can we give you lift somewhere?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Yes, I want to go to Albert Hall.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Afraid the Albert Hall's a bit off our beat. Suppose we drop you at the nearest taxi rank?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: All right.   Let's go.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Hello.   Hello.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Everybody out into the corridor.   Hurry

Speaker: butler
Dialogue: Do what he says. Come on. It will only be a minute. Come on, all of you -- out.

Speaker: woman cook
Dialogue: This embassy -- there's always something queer going on.

Speaker: another voice
Dialogue: Bringing people in, in secret...

Dialogue: Give me the Swiss Embassy every time, there's neutrality for you!

Speaker: uniformed attendant
Dialogue: Seats at a guinea. Starting Room three and six --

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: I would like to see the manager, please.

Speaker: uniformed attendant
Dialogue: I'm sorry, madam, The manager's on duty in the lobby. So's his assistant.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Please, I must speak to one of them. Which are they?

Speaker: uniformed attendant
Dialogue: Over there somewhere...

Speaker: rien
Dialogue: You have a very nice little boy, madame.

Speaker: j0
Dialogue: Where Is he?     Where is he?

Speaker: ticket collector
Dialogue: Your ticket, madam?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: If you don't mind, I'm just looking for someone.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Then he didn't kill him?

Speaker: assistant manager
Dialogue: Your wife saved him -- it is only a small flesh wound...Oh here he is now...you must come and meet him...don't be nervous...I'll get the aide to present you...it will be all right  Would you present the lady to the prime minister?

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: I'll report to you fully at the Embassy, Your Excellency. In the meantime...

Speaker: woburn
Dialogue: Mr. Prime Minister, this is the lady who --

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: My dear lady, I shall be for ever in your debt.

Speaker: woburn
Dialogue: And this is her husband --

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: A pleasure, my dear sir...  I trust you will permit me to wait upon you tomorrow and to express the depth of my gratitude.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: It wasn't -- it wasn't --

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: Oh but it was, my dear lady.

Speaker: woburn
Dialogue: I think Mr. Buchanan would like to talk to you.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Where's our boy?   Where's Hank?

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: We can talk if you'll come in here.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: So you both know the time and place all along.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Don't be a fool.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: An odd coincidence -- both of you turning up here.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Too bad you didn't contact your assistant. He sent us both here.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: I beg your pardon.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: You see, we finally needed that help you offered. We still need it.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Buchanan.     We still need it.

Dialogue: Sir?

Dialogue: We've questioned the woman. Said she bought a ticket that happened to place her in the same box with the man that did the shooting. Doesn't know anything -- but if she does, she's not talking.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: I'll see her later.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Very good, sir.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: There's still plenty of room for hope, Mrs. McKenna...

Dialogue: His Excellency will see you now.

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: Yes...yes...I see. Well if the woman won't talk, she won't talk and that's that, I suppose. All right.

Dialogue: Excuse me sir, I have a lot to explain to you -- something very unusual has happened. I must also have the money to pay our French marksman.

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: Wouldn't it be superfluous, considering that he's dead?

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: His aim wasn't quite as good as you led me to expect. The target merely received a slight flesh wound in the arm. Worse than useless.

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: Then your French friend panicked, and made a fatal crash -- landing on the floor of the Albert Hall.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: I don't see how you can hold me responsible. He was most warmly recommended by our people in Marrakesh...

Dialogue: I'm glad you're able to treat the matter so lightly. I am holding a reception here this evening. In a few minutes, I have to welcome our Prime Minister as my guest of honor -- when I hope and expected that he would be totally unable to attend. That amuses you, no doubt?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: I don't know what to say ...

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: No. But I do. You've muddled everything from the start. Kidnapping that child in Marrakesh...Don't you realize that Americans dislike having their children kidnapped?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: How else could I make sure the American would hold his tongue?

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: And then, to crown it all, you get cold feet and come running along here to hide -- and bring the child with you: Don't you see what you've done to the diplomatic status of this Embassy?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: I didn't think...I only thought...

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: How are you going to get the child out of here, eh? Eh? Eh? Eh?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: There's no difficulty about that, surely? The car --

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: You English intellectuals will be the death of us all.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: I'll think of some method.   Just give me time....

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: Time!

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: I want the child removed from this Embassy, and removed in such a way that he won't be able to say any more where he has been tonight.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Right, I'll see to it..

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: butler
Dialogue: Your Excellency, the Princess should be arriving at any moment.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: ...recognized him, and he recognized me. So he jumped for it. And that is all.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: Trying to liquidate one of their own big-shots. I wish they'd stick to their usual custom, and do it in their own country...

Speaker: woburn
Dialogue: Hello.  Hold on.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: Buchanan speaking.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: Right.    Bye.

Dialogue: The Draytons are at the Embassy.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: We have ways of finding out -- from the inside.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: If the Draytons are at the Embassy, Hank has to be there too!

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: You're probably right.   But we can do nothing.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Why can't you?

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: Every Embassy in a foreign country has extra-territorial rights.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: What does that mean in common language?

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: As far as we're concerned, this Embassy stands on foreign soil.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Does that mean they can steal children and get away with it?

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: We could have the Foreign Office serve a writ on the Ambassador.

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: ...You know, I'm not responsible for the complications of International Law...

Speaker: buchanan
Dialogue: ...If only we had positive proof that the boy really is in there.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: What's the telephone number of this Embassy.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: What are you thinking about, Ben?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: I'm going to speak to the Minister himself.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: May I speak to the Prime Minister, please?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Tell him the lady who saved his life wants to speak to him. Its important.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: What am I supposed to say, Ben? I don't know --  Ben, half looking at Woburn and Buchanan, gives her instructions.

Speaker: bfn
Dialogue: He said he wanted to visit us soon so he could thank you.

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: My dear lady...This is a charming surprise...

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: Delighted, delighted, delighted. The Ambassador, too, will be delighted. Any friends of mine are friends of his. We will drink a little toast to your country and to mine. Peacefully we will co-exist...Yes?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: He said -- all right.

Dialogue: Good even. Would you come this way, please? The Prime Minister is waiting for you.

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: Good evening, good evening!

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: This is the charming lady who saved my life at the Concert!

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: Madame, you saved the life of the one man, who is irreplaceable in our Country.

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: They tell me you are the famous Jo Conway, Madame?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Yes.   I'm Jo Conway.

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: Do you think perhaps Madame might be persuaded to sing?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: I'm sure she would be glad to... wouldn't you dear?

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Well, I don't know.     It's been some time...

Speaker: prime minister
Dialogue: I beg you, Madame. A tranquil coda to conclude a dramatic evening!

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: All right.   I'm very flattered.

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: Darling would you see that the Prime Minister has a very good seat.

Speaker: aide
Dialogue: Would you like to sit down, sir?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: No...I'll just stand over here.

Speaker: hank
Dialogue: That's my Mother's voice!    That's my Mother singing!

Speaker: hank
Dialogue: That's her!    I know it!

Speaker: hank
Dialogue: I guess so.

Speaker: mrs drayton
Dialogue: Then go on -- whistle it.   Whistle it as loud as you can.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: You two wait in the mail room.   I'll bring him down.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: I won't be a minute.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: I don't think you want to start any shooting, Drayton -- with all those people downstairs, and police outside.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Precisely my own notion, my dear.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: I'm sure you'll ba sensible, and help me out of here?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Don't ask me for help, you miserable....

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: You wouldn't want your father to get hurt, would you?

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: We'll go down the stairs   together in a casual sort of way. Then    we'll stroll along to the nearest taxi   rank. I trust there won't be any   emotional outbursts...

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: There won't be. Hank -- don't say or do anything.

Speaker: drayton
Dialogue: Shall we go?

Speaker: hank
Dialogue: Mummy.

Speaker: jo
Dialogue: Hank.

Dialogue: I'm sorry we were gone so long, Val, but we had to go and pick up Hank.
